title: R43898
content: Recent legislation has extended certain expiring provisions in the Internal Revenue Code, making some temporary provisions permanent. The American Taxpayer Relief Act (ATRA) reduced tax policy uncertainty by permanently extending most tax cuts enacted in 2001 and 2003. ATRA also temporarily extended provisions that had expired at the end of 2011 or 2012 through 2013. The American Taxpayer Relief Act (ATRA) reduced tax policy uncertainty by permanently extending most tax cuts enacted in 2001 and 2003. A number of provisions that had expired at the end of 2011 or 2012 were temporarily extended through 2013 under ATRA. The Tax Increase Prevention Act of 2014 extended provisions that expired at the end of 2013 through 2014. The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2016 either made permanent or temporarily extended all tax provisions that had expired at the end of 2014. The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2016 (P.L. 114-113) made permanent or temporarily extended all tax provisions that had expired at the end of 2014, known as "tax extenders." Many of these provisions, such as the research tax credit, had been extended multiple times before being made permanent. In the 114th Congress, there was significant debate on tax extenders. The tax provisions known as "tax extenders" were extended multiple times before being made permanent in P.L. 114-113. The debate in the 114th Congress focused on whether expired tax provisions should be made permanent or temporarily extended. Ultimately, all expired tax provisions were either temporarily extended or made permanent in P.L. 114-113, reducing uncertainty in the tax code. The tax extenders were either temporarily extended or made permanent in P.L. 114-113, reducing uncertainty in the tax code. However, some provisions are still set to expire at the end of 2016, sparking debate in the 114th Congress on whether they should be extended. This report provides an overview of tax extenders. More detailed information on specific extender provisions can be found in other CRS reports. It also included a two-year moratorium on the medical device excise tax. The term "tax extender" refers to expiring tax provisions temporarily extended by Congress for short periods of time.
